fields.content_html:
Most advice is bad, and you know it. When someone suggests you do something, their thoughts are actually helpful maybe a quarter of the time. Advice tends to fall short for two reasons: First, giving and receiving instructions is easier than asking and considering questions, but instructions often aren’t the most useful form of advice. Second, it’s hard to say things that are both specific and relevant. This column dives into these two reasons before suggesting a trick for avoiding bad advice. But first, I need to distinguish practical advice from life advice.

Life advice and practical advice

Life advice concerns things like whether to get married, whether to move to Chicago, whether to go to law school, if it makes sense to have another kid, whether to break ties with a family member, et cetera. Practical advice concerns things like how to do a proper deadlift, how to get a job, how to learn Italian, where to find the best kebab in a neighborhood, how to get a baby to stop crying, et cetera. I struggle to nail down the distinction. The best I can do is the above list of examples and the general observation that life advice tends to be ungoogleable and about “should I?”, while practical advice tends to be googleable and about “how?”.

For life advice, questions are better than stories, and stories are better than instructions:

 

But it’s the other way around for practical advice:

For practical advice, questions are annoying and instructions are helpful. For life advice, questions are essential and instructions are a last resort. People can usually solve their own life problems when nudged with the right questions. Even when they can’t and advice-givers need to give direct suggestions, instructions are better when preceded with lots of questions.

With this distinction between practical and life advice in mind, we can move onto the first reason why most advice is bad.

Reason #1: Instructions are easier to give and receive than questions

I once met a sensitive financial planner whose office is full of Kleenex boxes. She asks her clients probing questions about family and lifestyle. It’s only after coming to a deep understanding of their values and motivations that she starts talking about IRAs and mutual funds. This is a lot of work. It would be easier for her to go to an online retirement calculator, punch in some numbers, and spit out a plan. It’s a lot of work for her clients too: the thoughtful financial planner said she often turns down people who won’t make themselves vulnerable enough to receive good advice. Instructions are easy to give and receive, but meaningful questions are difficult to ask and difficult to answer.[1]

In the internet age, when we ask people for advice it’s usually ungoogleable life advice. But asking the questions necessary for good life advice is hard, so advice-givers often skip the work of figuring out the advice-seeker’s circumstances and simply start giving instructions. They might start speaking to a younger version of themselves or “kids these days” instead of to the advice-seeker sitting in front of them. Advice-seekers bear some responsibility for bad advice too—I’m guarded, so I get awful life advice. Those of us with avoidant attachment styles can only get good life advice from old friends or people with exceptional interpersonal skills.

Life advice is harder to come by and more valuable than practical advice. But we tend to receive bad life advice because questions are messier than instructions.

Reason #2: It’s hard to say things that are both specific and relevant

My high school physics teacher showed my class two important elements of a good measurement: precision and accuracy. He explained the difference with a graphic that looked something like this:


Likewise, there are two elements to good advice: specificity and relevance. This is true whether the advice comes in the form of instructions, stories, or questions. I’m going to walk through the three ways the darts can miss the bullseye, and advice can fail to be both specific and relevant. Then we’ll finally get to that one weird trick. Let’s say you’re wondering how to get a good grade in constitutional law.

Vague and irrelevant advice


You ask someone how to do well on the exam, and they answer, “I always say: honesty is the best policy.” This is my favorite kind of bad advice since it often comes from a place of love (e.g., your parent who didn’t go to law school). But it does just as often come from indifference (e.g., someone who got dragged onto a panel discussion). In any case, it’s not helpful.

Vague but relevant advice


Now let’s say your advice-giver tells you, “Go to class, do the readings, and find good outlines.” This advice is better. But it’s still not specific—it doesn’t tell you what to do during class, how to approach the readings, what to do with an outline, or how to allocate your time.

Vague advice can be helpful, but its helpfulness depends entirely on who is being addressed. Consider the prominent internet shower thought, “How is it that ‘the pen is mightier than the sword’ but ‘actions speak louder than words?’” The answer is the audience—a thoughtless goon needs the first vague aphorism while a hesitant waffler needs the second. Usually though, people deliver vague advice without really knowing the person receiving it. So it’s like a tape measure with only foot markers: accurate, but not super helpful. We need specificity.

Specific but irrelevant advice


Now let’s say your advice-giver insists you must pay attention to Justice Kennedy’s concurrence in Parents Involved if you want an A. They tell you the way Kennedy avoids the typical modalities of constitutional argument provides deep insights into the frameworks that underpin the course. This is the most common and the most frustrating sort of bad advice: hyper-specific to the advice-giver’s prior successes but irrelevant to the advice-seeker. An approach that helps one student write an effective policy essay might be useless to another. Columnist Mary Schmich warns, “Advice is a form of nostalgia. Dispensing it is a way of fishing the past from the disposal, wiping it off, painting over the ugly parts and recycling it for more than it’s worth.”

Specific and relevant advice


Now imagine your advice-giver has a long conversation with you. They learn about your performance on a midterm exam: You showed a strong command of how the Constitution limits and empowers the federal government but struggled with a policy question about the consequences of Brown (you’re an international student without much context for American history). Your advice-giver points you to the exact slides you need to review in order to build a perspective on the development of constitutional law, and provides feedback on some practice essays you sketch out in the weeks leading up to the exam.

Good advice is rare and you should cherish it. And it’s much easier to provide specific and relevant practical advice than life advice. Which leads us to that trick.

The one weird trick for avoiding bad advice

The one weird trick for avoiding bad advice is to never ask for life advice. Never ask for anything resembling life advice. Never give anyone the slightest suggestion you’re in the market for life advice or it will come, unsolicited and unhelpful.

As far as I can tell, the only two ways to give good (i.e., specific and relevant) life advice are to already know someone well or to ask them many questions over a long period of time. Advice-givers rarely have the time for this. So just don’t ask for life advice, and you’ll avoid a lot of bad guidance.

Getting good practical advice is still hard but it’s doable, especially at Columbia Law. If you’ve already worked out the “should I?” questions in life, this school has world-class answers to the “how?” questions. PIPS and OPSC can show you how to get a job. Professors can show you how to analyze cases. Student organizations can show you how to live frugally and find community in New York. Kat’s Verdict advice column can show you how to find free food on campus.

The advice you find at CLS is good, but it’s more like the advice you’d get from Target’s customer service desk than the advice you’d get from a rabbi. Take advantage of this school’s deep wells of practical advice while steering clear of people telling you what to do with your life.

Daniel Bugingo is a 2L and a Writer for The Verdict.

1 This is reflected in the cost of advice: Counselors and life coaches cost hundreds of dollars an hour while search engines have made instructions free (of course, people get free advice from friends and mentors, but you often get what you pay for).

fields.title: On the 2024 Election
fields.content_html:
As a disciple of legal realism like everyone else at this law school, I’ll admit that what I’m about to say is no doubt influenced by my values, prejudices, and political opinions. But what I hope to accomplish here is to lay out my opinions about the return of Trump to the presidency in terms that seek to rise above political differences. My observations are threefold. First, Trump represents the American electorate’s rejection of the principles of the rule of law, born from their distrust of this country’s legal system. This reflects the lamentable condition of this country’s civic discourse and represents a failure by those who built, utilize, and benefit from this legal system to really “do justice.” Cf. Berger v. United States, 295 U.S. 78, 88 (1935) (describing the U.S. Attorney’s duty as one to ensure “that justice shall be done”). Second, it has been increasingly difficult, at least for me, to differentiate between illegality and bad policy. Trump and his associates so frequently challenge and sometimes successfully overturn legal norms that every policy decision seemingly becomes a legal question. A well-functioning political system, though, should not produce policy outcomes that touch the red wires of the law so frequently. Finally, we as law students know that “bad times make bad law.” The first Trump administration certainly delivered on that front, and we should expect the second Trump administration to produce even more “bad” precedents that will control for most of our professional careers.

First, the American electorate sending Trump back to the White House signals its rejection of, or at least indifference to, the principles of the rule of law. “The Government of the United States has been emphatically termed a government of laws, not of men.” Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137, 163 (1803). When discussing the separation of powers, James Madison wrote in Federalist No. 51 that “[i]f men were angels, no government would be necessary. . . . In framing a government which is to be administered by men over men, . . . you must . . . oblige [the government] to control itself.” And in Federalist No. 78, Alexander Hamilton argued that “all the reservations of particular rights or privileges” to the people and the States depend on an independent judiciary as well as an executive that respects such judgments. But Trump famously lacks such self-control in general and respect for the law in particular, especially when he loses in fair contests, making him particularly dangerous to this American experiment in democracy.

Returning Trump to the presidency challenges the rule of law in many ways, even if we disregard his guilty verdicts in New York and federal prosecutions in D.C. and Florida. Trump is a man who incited supporters to storm the Capitol after losing effectively every court case challenging the 2020 election results. His presence on the Colorado ballot depended on a SCOTUS ruling not on the merits of whether he engaged in insurrection, as the Colorado Supreme Court upheld, but on the procedural question of which institution could so determine. And after almost 250 years of this republic’s existence, it is his flirtations with criminality that gave birth to the doctrine that presidents are uniquely above this country’s criminal laws. Trump has done something incredible in these examples, accomplishing a trifecta of disrespect for the rule of law. He does not respect decisions unfavorable to him rendered by duly authorized tribunals. He exploits gaps in the letter of the law in order to violate its spirit. And he managed to convince the judicial branch to abandon its own commitment to equality before the law. True, the highest court of the land gave its seal of approval to the latter two of these feats, but just because SCOTUS pronounced something legal doesn’t mean it cannot also be contrary to the principles of our constitutional design. The Supreme Court, after all, is “infallible only because [it is] final.” Brown v. Allen, 344 U.S. 443, 540 (1953) (Jackson, J., concurring). Merely pressing those arguments in public and in court should have been politically disqualifying. In a sane world, such a man would not be entrusted to “take care that the laws be faithfully executed,” Const. art. II, Sec. 3, because he has proven that he knows anything but how to do that.

Not only does Trump himself pose a threat to the rule of law, his return points to a deeper problem in the country that sent him back to that post. It means that a majority of the electorate does not care about how their preferred candidate accomplishes policy goals that they believe, rightly or wrongly, will benefit them, as long as they get it done. But the “how” preserves the voters’ very ability to vote in their preferred candidates each election and to not suffer from arbitrary and capricious applications of state power when the political wind shifts, or when Trump’s own preferences change–for example, when suggesting after the Parkland mass shooting that the government should “take the guns first, go through due process second.”

And yet opinion polls suggest that Americans still overwhelmingly (83%) believe that the president must always obey the law and the courts, even though the percentage of citizens who trust those same courts has declined to 56%. While almost everyone believes in the importance of the rule of law (96%), people have “growing concerns over the actual implementation and integrity of the rule of law in the country.”

How can these statistics be squared with the electorate’s embrace of Trump? While 83% of Americans may think in the abstract that presidents should follow the law and the courts, if asked specifically about Trump or about a specific Trump policy that is enjoined by the courts, the result might be a lot different. And 83% of people thinking that presidents should follow the law and judicial rulings does not necessarily mean that they will renounce him if he actually violates clear legal obligations, especially given widespread misgivings about the operation of the courts. Only 47% of Americans believe that judges decide cases in an independent manner, and only 31% believe that courts are not biased toward money or influence. Students of the law can have nuanced debates about the merits and limits of judicial supremacy and to what extent other branches of government interpret the law. But in the real world, it is a dangerous thing if a president could win more, not less, support for disobeying or ignoring the decisions of courts that the public distrusts. After all, we do not consider President Jackson, who reportedly said that “[Chief Justice] John Marshall has made his decision, now let him enforce it,” an example to emulate. Is it such a surprise that Trump is a big admirer of Jackson’s?

If it is concerns about the “actual implementation and integrity of the rule of law” that motivate people, then we must look inward at the failure of legal professionals—lawyers, prosecutors, judges—to “do justice” in our day-t0-day work. There are obvious things that we can do to ameliorate the decline of public trust in the justice system. Legal professionals have a responsibility to make the law, which can sound like indecipherable codewords, more accessible to everyday Americans. Our Constitutional scheme—for instance, the public’s First Amendment right to access to criminal trials, see Globe Newspaper Co. v. Superior Court, 457 U.S. 596 (1982)—assumes that the law is understandable to the public. People are fearful and distrusting of what they are not familiar with. To restore the public’s trust in the law, we must help them understand it.

In dealing with clients, lawyers can perhaps do more to break the law down into first principles that are understandable and persuasive to lay clients. More importantly, some of us will have the honor of serving as judges one day, and many of us will pen their opinions as clerks. When writing opinions, those in a judicial role can try harder to explain the rationale behind a legal doctrine afresh rather than simply citing a case that established it. Contra New York State Rifle & Pistol Association, Inc. v. Bruen, 597 U.S. 1, 20 (2022) (citing District of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. 570 (2008), for the proposition that Second Amendment right to bear arms “does not depend on service in the militia” without sparing just one sentence to explain why). And it doesn’t help when the Supreme Court declines to rule on partisan gerrymandering at least in part because it thinks its rulings will simply be misinterpreted as partisan favoritism. (For example, at oral argument for Gill v. Whitford, 585 U.S. 48 (2018), Chief Justice Roberts stated: “[T]he intelligent man on the street is going to say that’s a bunch of baloney. It must be because the Supreme Court preferred Democrats over the Republicans. And that’s going to come out one case after another as these cases are brought in every state.”) If the Court is really conscious about public perceptions of its legitimacy, then it should do the hard work to be more persuasive and fulfill its constitutional duty to “say what the law is.” Marbury, 5 U.S. at 177.

Second, the next Trump presidency will make it even harder to separate questions about the wisdom of policy from questions of its legality, to the detriment of constructive policy discussions. People have increasingly been turning to the courts to resolve issues that they are unable to resolve through the legislative process. This tactic can amount to asking a court to interfere with democratic prerogatives, a power courts are at times reluctant to exercise. Cf. United States v. Richardson, 418 U.S. 166, 173 (1974) (justifying the denial of plaintiff’s standing with his ability to “assert his views in the political forum or at the polls,” “[s]low, cumbersome, and unresponsive though the traditional electoral process may be thought at times”). The first Trump administration saw an explosion of nationwide injunctions. Post Massachusetts v. EPA, there has also been a steady increase in state-led litigation against the federal government. During the Obama administration, states sued the federal government 80 times; in the first Trump administration, that figure was 155; and in the Biden administration, as of November 30, 2024, the figure was 121.

One popular explanation of this phenomenon has been the dysfunction of Congress and thus its inability to have productive policy dialogues with the Executive. Developments in the Law — Court Reform, 137 Harv. L. Rev. 1701, 1707 (2024) (“As gridlock in Congress has forced Presidents to turn to executive action, so too have nationwide injunctions increased.”). But this partial explanation does not account for an observable difference in the amount of lawsuits during consecutive presidential administrations, seemingly without regard to the composition of the two houses of Congress. The President’s party did not have control of both houses of Congress during about half of Bush Jr.’s presidency, six out of eight years of Obama’s, and half of Biden’s, while Trump enjoyed two years of a Republican trifecta and governed for two years without it. Meanwhile, there were only 6 nationwide injunctions during Bush Jr.’s two terms, 12 during Obama’s two terms, and 14 during Biden’s term through his third year in office, compared to 64 in Trump’s first term. The better explanation, perhaps, is that Trump is more prone to abusing administrative law, while Biden has been more of a magnet for lawsuits initiated by politically-minded plaintiffs.

Multi-state-led suits against the federal government, for which there is a ready database, illustrate this point. I consider the cases that have been resolved so far, which amount to 117 for the Trump administration and 34 for Biden’s, rather than the overall number of suits against the federal government (155 vs. 121), because I use the success or failure of the states’ suit as a rough indicator of whether the suit was meritorious or for political show. During the first Trump administration, a strong plurality of them, 57, concerned environmental issues, which were certainly not the most controversial during the Trump administration. Among these, states won 46 cases and lost 4, with 7 cases ending up neither a win nor a loss (for the database’s purposes, typically this means that the plaintiff voluntarily withdrew the suit). Some of the more controversial Trump policies, such as those related to immigration, were also challenged in court. Only 14 closed cases concerned immigration, and among them states won 13 and lost 1. Overall, states were successful in 82 cases against the Trump administration, unsuccessful in 18, and came to a draw in 16 cases (with 1 case unaccounted for).

In comparison, among the 34 closed cases so far where states sued the Biden administration, the category with the most cases at 11 is “healthcare.” These were all politically sensitive cases during the COVID-19 era about vaccine mandates or mask mandates. States won 10 of these cases, and the remaining case became moot. Then there have been 7 immigration cases, about twice as frequent as under the Trump administration. States won 4 of these and lost 2, while 1 case was a draw.

What this data tells us is that a second Trump administration will likely continue the trend of not following the law when pursuing their political objectives, even when doing so wins them few political points. Many of his cabinet picks, such as RFK Jr. as HHS Secretary, Lee Zeldin as EPA Administrator, Kristi Noem as DHS Secretary, Pete Hegseth as Secretary of Defense, and Chris Wright as Energy Secretary, who were seemingly chosen based on their unfamiliarity with the levers of the federal government or the agency they are slated to lead, are also unlikely to respect the processes the law requires of them.

This is not just a rule-of-law issue. In a well-functioning system, policymaking should not so frequently be confronting legal substance and procedure. The more energy we spend debating the legality of a specific policy, the less we retain for debating the wisdom of the policy and the longer we take to actually address issues this country faces. For example, after an agency regulation is struck down for not following the APA, the agency must try the rulemaking process again, which takes up additional time and money. It’s a waste of resources for both the government (and by extension, us as taxpayers) and regulated industries, distracting them from their actual business and thus the country’s economic growth. The Trump administration’s seemingly cavalier attitude toward following the law when pursuing its policy objectives distracts us from substantive debates about policy that, for better or worse, actually has practical consequences. Instead of discussing whether a particular policy choice is good or bad, effective or ineffective, we are constantly held hostage by the question of whether a policy is legal or illegal. If Trump actually wants to improve government efficiency, perhaps he should start with instructing his administration to get things right on the first try.

Third and finally, we in law school are familiar with the phrase “bad times make bad law.” This was true of the first Trump administration. So I shudder to think what legal precedents a second Trump administration will generate—precedents that could easily persist for the entirety of our professional careers.

To begin, I do take a bit of an issue with the phrase “bad times make bad law.” To nobody’s surprise, the phrase is not universally true. Bad times certainly make law: When the political process is dysfunctional, people turn to the courts to fight their ideological battles. But not all of these cases from “bad times” are bad. Any 1L who has taken Constitutional Law understands that the more turbulent the times, the more impactful the SCOTUS opinions from those eras. To this day, Reconstruction-era cases still define civil rights doctrine, Civil Rights Movement-era cases First Amendment jurisprudence, and Vietnam War-era cases presidential war powers. Without some of this litigation, we wouldn’t even have judicial interpretations of some important constitutional provisions. And some of the most controversial issues that came before the court were resolved, in hindsight, correctly.

What makes bad law in bad times, however, is a Supreme Court incapable of taking a long-term view, even though it is the only branch of government that is institutionally equipped to do so by virtue of its members’ lifetime appointments. That is what happened in cases like Korematsu, decided with an eye toward the war effort and not much else, and Dred Scott, when Justice Taney thought he could forestall the Civil War.

And the Supreme Court has sure been short-sighted in pivotal case after pivotal case during Trump’s administration and after Trump reshaped it. I’m not even talking about disappointments like Dobbs, where we are still waiting to see how Justice Alito’s quip that “[w]omen are not without electoral or political power” will shake out on the national stage. 597 U.S. 215, 289 (2022). Any student who has taken Leg Reg can tell you that administrative law is but a tool that executives of either ideological persuasion can use to their advantage. Changing administrative law doctrine for the short-term gain or loss of a particular president would simply backfire when the next president wants to switch gears. Yet the Supreme Court was intent on granting the president expansive “executive power” to fire executive branch officials, like the head of the CFPB, at will when it was Trump who wanted the power to do so, only for Biden to fire Trump’s appointee, undermining the political independence of an agency where it is crucial. It was also bent on taking away the executive branch’s power to make reasonable interpretations of ambiguous statutes when it was Biden they were ruling against, only to see Trump back in the White House, seeking to make sweeping changes to the administrative state while interpreting those very same statutes.

The most egregious example, perhaps, is granting Trump almost absolute immunity from criminal prosecution for official acts, a doctrine never before needed in this country’s almost 250-year history. Trump v. United States, 603 U.S. 593 (2024). Chief Justice Roberts and the fellow justices in the majority might have thought that they’re actually protecting Clinton, Obama, and Biden from retributive criminal investigations and prosecutions that Trump was likely to order if he were reelected. That would be an incredibly short-sighted consideration, however—especially given that Trump will at most be in power for another four years, and that the range of things that a president can now do without worrying about criminal penalties far outstrips the narrow power to direct an improper prosecution of a former president against whom he holds a grudge. But their ruling may stay on the books forever, since it’s unlikely that this issue will ever arise again at the Supreme Court.

And think about what will come next. The trend of giving the president more and more control over his executive branch will likely continue when litigation arises from the Trump administration’s attempt to implement Project 2025’s Schedule F scheme in order to replace career civil servants with MAGA loyalists. Trump might also seek to take more direct control over the Federal Reserve, and the exceptions SCOTUS preserved for such bodies in Seila Law might not hold out for long. A central bank beholden to political considerations is simply a bad idea, since an Executive motivated by reelection is more likely to disregard the longer-term inflationary pressures from monetary policies that boost short-term economic growth. There might also be lawsuits concerning the deployment of the military or national guard to enforce immigration laws or to clamp down on protest activities, direction of politically motivated prosecutions, or closing of the border yet again while motivated by religious animus. I am not confident that, given the current Court’s expansive views of executive power and its short-sightedness, it will meaningfully constrain Trump for the benefit not only of people living during his administration, but also those who come long after.

So should we pack our bags, find a country that still allows Americans to stay and work for a long time or grab our foreign passports, and leave? Or just tune out from politics? That’s certainly a temptation for many, and I’ll admit I haven’t been following the news as enthusiastically as before. But as my parents have always told me, and as I was glad to hear Tim Walz say on the campaign trail, even if “[you’re] not that into politics, . . . too damn bad, politics is into you.” Like I argued earlier, to restore people’s trust in the rule of law, we must make sure that the law is comprehensible to the people. By virtue of being educated in the law, we bear a special responsibility for helping to achieve that. So maybe you took a chill pill and ignored some family members’ out-there political rant at Thanksgiving dinner this time around—totally understandable—but next time, talk to them. Talk to them about your thoughts on the merits of a policy, not just its legality. And talk to them about where the law is going and the merits, the rationale, and, yes, the history and tradition of those doctrines. Break things down into first principles and explain what the real-life impacts are on the person you’re talking to and the people they know. It’s one thing to explain how Justice Gorsuch read sexual orientation into sex as a textualist matter in Bostock; it’s another to point out how treating the LGBTQ+ community equally in the workplace is good not just for their dignity, but also the economy. We are specially equipped to do both, so do both. As Ben Franklin once reportedly said, the United States is “a republic, if you can keep it.” This is how we keep it.

Albert is a 3L at CLS.

fields.preview_text: “Dear Kat, Finals are coming up. I’m stressed, unprepared, and starting to panic. I might survive by sheer force of will and excessive amounts of caffeine, but is there another way? How will I get through this?”
fields.content_html:
“Dear Kat, Finals are coming up. I’m stressed, unprepared, and starting to panic. I might survive by sheer force of will and excessive amounts of caffeine, but is there another way? How will I get through this?”

Dear Reader,

There might be another way, but I don’t know one! If you do, please call me at (678) 999-8212.

Let’s take a deep breath because more stress means higher cortisol levels, which means worse focus and sleep. Remember: You have been learning throughout this entire semester, not just since you started outlining (or whenever you will start). Instead of making a study plan purely based on maximizing content consumption, consider how you best retain info. I also suggest minimizing daily choices you have to make, like what to eat or where to study. It may not do much, but having less decision fatigue generally may help you be consistent and stick to a schedule.

You may feel like you can’t do practice tests until your outline is done or you have reviewed everything. This won’t resonate with everyone, but if it resonates with you, ignore that feeling! It is likely just a manifestation of procrastination (mmm that rolls off the tongue). Practice exams are terrifying and it is easy to logic yourself out of them. Just do them. You don’t need to replicate an exam setting perfectly or do an entire exam in one sitting. All I can say is that knowing the material doesn’t matter (exam-wise) if you aren’t comfortable putting it in writing. Also, test out Exam4 before your exams because it is not user friendly!

It will be over before you know it. It’s been lovely advising you this semester. Keep the questions flowing and go see Gladiator II (this is not a paid ad).

Best,
Kat

Katerina Kakkis is a 3L and a Contributor for The Verdict.

fields.title: The Five Most Romantic 1L Cases
fields.preview_text: Valentine’s Day is the libertarian’s holiday. The government usually has an interest in regulating things as unfair and dangerous as romance, but in love we are free—heartbroken, mogged on, gaslit, bankrupted, ghosted, and embarrassed, but free. Here are the five most romantic 1L cases.
fields.content_html:
Valentine’s Day is the libertarian’s holiday.1 The government usually has an interest in regulating things as unfair and dangerous as romance, but in love we are free—heartbroken, mogged on, gaslit, bankrupted, ghosted, and embarrassed, but free. Lovers are free to remain childless, free to marry who they love, free to avoid tort creditors, and free to do whatever is going on in Michael H. Here are the five most romantic 1L cases.

B-tier

In re Estate of Kievernagel, 83 Cal. Rptr. 3d 311 (2008)

“No ma’am, your late husband made it clear he wanted his sperm destroyed,” is how one attack outline describes this case. Iris Kievernagel could not convince her husband Joseph to have children in life or in death. While I feel bad for Iris, this B-tier romance does create some puzzles for us budding legal eagles. Why does the court accept Joseph’s consent form and destroy his potential progeny, but reject the will in Eyerman (holding due to “public policy”2 you can’t destroy a deceased woman’s house despite her really wanting it destroyed upon her death)? Was Joseph’s sperm intellectual property? Will the president, the self-proclaimed “father of IVF,”3 issue an executive order clarifying these issues?

Michael H. v. Gerald D., 491 U.S. 110 (1989)

Michael has a baby with Carole, a model who lives next door. Unfortunately, Carole is married to Gerald, a French oil executive. Gerald’s name ends up on the baby’s birth certificate, and the couple won’t let Michael have a relationship with his biological child.

So Michael stands on the 14th amendment substantive due process tradition to assert a right to see his out-of-wedlock child. But the Court decides it’s super constitutional for California to prioritize Carole’s marriage with Gerald over Michael’s relationship with his child.4 S-tier drama, B-tier romance.

A-tier

Obergefell v. Hodges, 576 U.S. 644 (2015)

I’m pretty sure Jim Obergefell liked his husband John more than vice versa when they met in 1992: “John liked to say for us, ‘It wasn’t love at first sight, it was love at third sight.’”5 John liked to say for us.

John Arthur was a confident, mister-steal-your-man type. Jim was diffident and still in the closet. But the second time they met, perhaps scared of being “condemned to live in loneliness,”6 Jim found the courage to solicit a date from John. And the third time they met, I guess John finally saw in Jim what Jim was seeing in John, and the rest is history. Obergefell broke ground for timid, low-charisma men everywhere.

Loving v. Virginia, 388 U.S. 1 (1967)

Hank Williams Jr.’s song “If Heaven Ain’t a Lot Like Dixie” is basically all my values and preferences inverted (“Take me to hell or New York City/It would be about the same to me”).7 But I unironically love that track since it’s cool when people are proud of where they’re from.

Mildred and Richard Loving grew up in Virginia, but they fled to Washington D.C. after police burst into their bedroom to enforce anti-miscegenation laws. D.C. was not for them: “[T]he Lovings missed family, friends and their easy country lifestyle in the rolling Virginia hills.”8 So inspired by the Civil Rights Movement, they went back home and got the Court to legalize their marriage. Very moving power couple: A-tier.

S-tier

Sawada v. Endo, 561 P.2d 1291 (1977)

But it’s 2025, wokeness is over, merit is back, and those DEI cases sure won’t be breaking into the S-tier.

Kokichi Endo injures a couple, the Sawadas, in a car accident, and it’s totally his fault. But when the Sawadas come after him for damages, Endo shields his property with the old “that’s not my stuff, that’s my marriage’s stuff, and wait my marriage just gave it to our son so you can’t touch it, ha!” trick.

Love conquers all, including creditors.

Daniel Bugingo is a 2L and a Writer for The Verdict.

2 If “because of public policy” means something more to you than “because I said so” please email me. I’m more than halfway through law school, it’s been explained to me several times, and it still strikes me as insanely Calvinball, even for law.

Gerald D., 491 U.S. at 129.

fields.title: On Jonathan Berry's "Beyond DEI: Rescuing the Human Person from Inhuman Law"
fields.preview_text: "Jonathan Berry's talk purported to tackle what he deemed a pressing issue in modern legal governance: the rising influence of large, anti-majoritarian corporations. fields.content_html:
On November 18, 2024, Columbia Law School’s Federalist Society hosted a lecture by Jonathan Berry, best known for co-authoring Project 2025. His talk, titled “Beyond DEI: Rescuing the Human Person from Inhuman Law,” purported to tackle what he deemed a pressing issue in modern legal governance: the rising influence of large, anti-majoritarian corporations. In actuality, the talk used flimsy arguments about the commodification of identity to justify dissolving DEI initiatives. Berry’s speech is reflective of the larger conservative push to scapegoat minorities as responsible for social issues, falling squarely in line with the fascist politics of President Donald Trump.

According to Berry, corporate commodification has two damaging implications. First, because high-ranking corporate officials skew left politically, liberal ideologies have an undue influence on policy. Second, large companies commodify identity and culture by selling the idea of “limitlessness” to brand products. As he described it, limitlessness encourages people to seek opportunities beyond their capabilities, presuming that their identity will compensate for their lack of qualifications.

Berry forwarded various solutions to the issue—from prohibiting companies from enacting DEI quotas through government regulation to beginning board meetings with the Pledge of Allegiance—that echoed policies proposed in his “Mandate for Leadership.” His advice to lecturees was to reject limitlessness and instead to recognize the constraints on their potential. In practice, this looks like only applying for summer positions that one believes she is actually qualified for rather than applying broadly.

On its face, Berry’s message of accepting one’s limits doesn’t seem problematic. The lecture began to unravel when Berry applied this argument to minority groups. Berry’s example of the commodification of Black identity was a bus advertisement that read “Wakanda Forever.” When prompted to explain the connection between “Wakanda Forever” and limitlessness, Berry simply repeated his earlier assertion without justifying how the advertisement targeted or commodified Black identity. Seemingly, Berry made the assumption that an advertising campaign for the most widely-watched media franchise aimed to promote false courage in Black people, solely because it featured a majority-Black cast.

To Berry’s credit, there is merit to his claim about the commodification of identity by large corporations. LGBT+ advocates have long critiqued “corporate pride” for exploiting the queer community for profit rather than meaningfully supporting queer rights. Where Berry errs is his assertion that this trend is unique to minority groups like queer and Black people, when in fact nearly every holiday is commodified. Pharmacies stock up on cards and flowers for Mother’s Day, department stores sell deer ears and stockings near Christmas, and Peeps make their annual appearance every Easter. Is CVS Pharmacy trying to sell the idea that motherhood has no constraints? Or, the more likely answer: Corporations capitalize on trends because they want to make money. Berry’s argument has little to do with liberal corporations forcing identity politics down America’s throat, and much more to do with them trying to maximize profits.

It may seem like Berry’s claims are simply misled, but analyzing the framing of the lecture reveals something more insidious. Although Berry spends most of his time critiquing large corporations generally, he chose to title his speech “Beyond DEI,” centering a particularly inflammatory, yet underdeveloped, theme of his talk. He cherry-picked examples of corporate commodification that focused on minority groups while glossing over ways in which every identity is commodified. For every Black Panther that chants “Wakanda Forever,” there are five Interstellars that say “Our destiny lies above us.” Berry’s choice to highlight minorities shows more of a commitment to dissolving DEI initiatives than critiquing corporate commodification. Why wouldn’t starting board meetings with the Pledge of Allegiance lead to the commodification of “American” identity? Why are “DEI hires” examples of corporate limitlessness, but nepotism hires are not? These glaring contradictions aren’t an issue to Berry. The only laws he views as “inhuman” are those that aim to benefit historically marginalized groups.

Berry’s speech is indicative of the modern conservative political strategy: Create a bogeyman and garner support from fear. While the myth of all-powerful woke corporations drives his argument, he provides little convincing evidence that DEI initiatives are uniquely harmful. Instead, he relies on buzzwords to inflame a non-issue, a tactic that has proven successful for many conservative thinkers. Most prominent among these is President Donald Trump, whose campaign boiled down to a politics of blame. Trump galvanized his base by targeting groups that posed some manufactured threat to civil society. Your neighborhoods are crime-riddled because of Mexicans illegally crossing the border. Your kids are unsafe because the liberals are doing transgender operations in grade school. Not even your pets are secure; Haitians in Springfield are eating the dogs and eating the cats. Where Trump and Berry align is the assertion of life-altering problems absent evidence of their existence or severity. Anyone with Google and basic discernment skills would realize that all of Trump’s threats are baseless. The success of Trump’s campaign revealed that empirics-based argument is much less effective than fear-mongering.

Although Trump and Berry’s weaponization of lies seems novel to those versed in modern American politics, there are clear analogies between this political strategy and the strategies of authoritarian rulers. In a 2024 article for the New Yorker, historian Timothy Snyder compared Trump’s disavowal of facts to the political strategies of fascist leaders like Putin, Mussolini, and Hitler. Everything that Trump says is the truth, and everyone that disagrees is the true fascist. This is particularly alarming when the “truth” justifies harming politically-vulnerable groups. Berry’s speech should not be viewed as a fringe conservative viewpoint, but an integral part of Trump-era fascism.

As law students, we have an obligation to fight back against dangerous narratives and hold speakers accountable for unfounded claims. Instead of prima facie dismissing beliefs like Berry’s as ridiculous, we have to critically engage with them to point out their contradictions and holes in logic. Only by remaining vigilant in our critical thinking can we resist a political schema seemingly adamant to crush it.

Elijah Pitt is a 1L and a Writer for The Verdict.
